It is when we build community with one another, when we cut through all the efforts to keep us afraid and angry, that  we see our destinies as tied.

That‚Äôs the work I‚Äôll continue to do, and I hope you‚Äôll join me.

Building solidarity is a painstaking process‚Äîespecially in a country and media environment as polarized and contentious ours is now. 

But we know it is the only path forward.
As a refugee and survivor of war, I see it is as a core responsibility to fight *all* injustice and engage *all* my colleagues in finding mechanisms of justice for the oppressed.

That is why I am a Member of the Black-Jewish caucus.

That is why I joined forces with Jan Schakowsky on a campaign to root out both Islamophobia and anti-Muslim hate and emphasize our shared values. https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/14/opinions/stop-white-nationalism-together-omar-schakowsky

That is why it is so important for us to build solidarity in the here and now, to make clear that the threats we face can only be solved if we see racism, anti-Muslim hate, and xenophobia as inextricably linked to antisemitism. 

That is the work we have tried to do in Congress.

Most of my colleagues across Congress may not be refugees themselves, but fleeing war and persecution only to find a refuge in the United States of America‚Äî*is* the Jewish-American experience. This binds us.

These threats are not a thing of the past.

It is not lost on me that today people go shoot up a synagogue because people think orgs like HIAS are helping refugees like me come to this country.

Today, groups like @theJewishvote, @JREJ, @jewishaction and @JCA_MN in my district are reminding us that the Jewish community have always been on the frontlines of social change, even amidst threats to their safety.
These values of fighting injustice and inequality are a core part of the faith, much as they are in the Muslim faith.

Heschel in particular was a deep inspiration to Martin Luther King and a moral leader of the movement.

The NAACP was founded not just by WEB Dubois, but Henry Moskowitz, a Jewish immigrant housing organizer and civil rights activists. https://rac.org/brief-history-jews-and-civil-rights-movement-1960s
It took a multiracial, multi-religious coalition of freedom fighters, including Jewish leaders like Rabbi Abraham Joshua Heschel, Kivie Kaplan, and Arnie Aronson, organizing in solidarity.

In this moment, we must stand in solidarity because what unites us is so much greater than what unites us. 

The Civil Rights movement of the 1960‚Äôs was not Black people working in isolation.

I also know that the Black community and the Jewish community have historically stood side-by-side in the fight against injustice and throughout our history we have faced efforts to divide us based on our differences.

I am someone who has survived war and experienced injustice firsthand, who is alive today because I was welcomed into this country as a refugee.

I know that many of my colleagues‚Äîboth Jewish and non-Jewish‚Äîdeeply share that commitment to fighting injustice. A brief thread.

The COVID-19 pandemic taught us a lot about our #unemploymentinsurance system.

The main lesson?

UI is in dire need of reform. 

Read our new brief here: https://twitter.com/JECDems/status/1410262658025197575 QT @JECDems NEW: Our new fact sheet highlights how #UnemploymentInsurance benefits the whole economy, stabilizing consumption and bolstering economic security. 

Here are the key takeaways--

In order to stabilize our economy & bolster resilience: 
1‚É£ UI eligibility should cover our modern labor force 
2‚É£ Benefit durations should last long enough to sustain a worker through a reasonable job search
3‚É£ Compensation levels should allow workers to cover basic necessities

Lastly, the system can‚Äôt work if benefit levels are inadequate to stabilize consumption and support families. 

In the US, average monthly rent for a 1-bedroom apt is $960, and yet 9 states paid less than $1000/mo on average in pre-tax in benefits. http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5JC7D-XIAAR8q9.jpg

UI also can‚Äôt bolster the economy if affected workers can‚Äôt access it. 

The share of workers who are ineligible is large and continues to grow. From 2010-2020, the share of gig workers‚Äîwho do not qualify for UI‚Äîincreased by 15%, writes @gregiacurci https://www.cnbc.com/2020/02/04/gig-economy-grows-15percent-over-past-decade-adp-report.html

However, #unemploymentinsurance cannot work for our economy if people cannot access it. 

Only 5 states and DC actually  provided UI to >50%  of short-term unemployed workers in 2014 http://pbs.twimg.com/media/E5JCx7XX0AENQqj.jpg

UI enhances labor market efficiency by: 
- Reducing the need for families to dip into savings 
- Allowing workers to search for a job that matches their skills and needs, leading to higher wages overall

More from @alixgouldwerth at @equitablegrowth: https://equitablegrowth.org/the-long-run-implications-of-extending-unemployment-benefits-in-the-united-states-for-workers-firms-and-the-economy/

#UnemploymentInsurance helps to keep workers in the labor force.

A standard requirement of receiving UI is that a worker is actively seeking work, and recipients are not eligible to continue receiving benefits if they are offered, but decline, suitable employment.

After a job loss, consumption of food and nondurable goods declines 6-9% . 

During the Great Recession, UI ‚Äúclosed more than 18% of the shortfall in GDP‚Äù from 2008 to 2010, according to @amprog. https://www.americanprogress.org/issues/poverty/reports/2016/06/16/138492/strengthening-unemployment-protections-in-america/

#Unemploymentinsurance is essential to sustain economic growth. 

UI stabilizes consumption by insuring that, even after a sudden job loss, covered workers can afford basic needs like housing, food, and medications.
